courses.subject: GESH
courses.title: College Symposium
courses.description: With the hallmark of twin characteristics of full residence and communal dining, S.H. Ho College offers a diversified environment in which students may grow. College students are expected to attend High Table Dinner normally once every month. Students enhance their social awareness and global linkages through talks and panel discussions by guest speakers after the formal dinner. Topics cover important aspects about humans and societies. Students are required to attend a minimum of 80% of High Table Dinner in a term in order to get a "satisfactory" grade for the course.
courses.learning_outcomes: It aims to broaden the horizon of students through talks and panel discussions by distinguished guests from different sectors of society. It affords students creativity and freedom in the exchange of knowledge and ideas with social leaders and peer students on topics important to life.
courses.course_syllabus: College students are required to attend High Table Dinner every month. In which distinguish guest speaker will give a speech on their specialty, students are expected to enhance their social awareness, and global linkages through talks and panel discussions. Topics cover important aspects about humans and societies.

courses.title: Orientation and Outreach

Professor WONG Kam Bo

courses.description:
The course title states the two related goals of this course, designed to help freshers develop a positive attitude towards college life. Through a careful sequenced selection of outdoor team activities, workshops, service and work projects, students are challenged to examine their orientation in life as they become college members in university. Success of the course hinges on balancing two axes of concern, namely, (1) between teamwork and personal development and (2) between inward reflection and outward expression.

This course is the major common learning experience of college students across all disciplines and years, initiating a fresher's identity as a member of S.H. Ho College. The activity-based approach facilitates the cohort of freshers to bond together as well as to integrate with the college community. As such, this induction course is a cornerstone of our College General Education ("CGE") Programme.

Mission: To induce communal learning in college life
Vision: College as a community of learners in dialogue
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Year 1 S.H. Ho College Students only
courses.course_syllabus: Students are organized in small teams and put through three stages of activities: Adventure (奮志), Reflection (明志) and Expression (明達). In the Adventure stage, students build teams that strive to explore and understand themselves and their new environment. In the Reflection stage, students attend classes to examine aspects of personal development, in relation to college and university communities, individual and society. In the final Expression stage, students initiate productions in some suitable form, such as writing, documentary, performance, as a personal or team response.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Early Feedback Collection System
* Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
* Student Consultative Meeting

courses.subject: GESH
courses.title: Service-learning: Bringing Knowledge to Life

meetings.instructor:
Dr SHIK Wai Yan Angela, 
Miss CHENG Lok Yi, 
Miss FUNG Wing Yan, 
Miss SZE Hiu Hei Corliss, 
Ms. NG Wing Yan

courses.description: For students entering Year 2 or above, this course intends to offer students the fundamental concepts of service-learning – an approach in which students could utilise their academic knowledge and skills to address community needs. Throughout the course, students would be equipped with the essential skill set and mindset to prepare for their upcoming service-learning project (SLP). Apart from designing their service plans, students would become civically informed and engaged citizens of the community.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For S.H. Ho College Year 2 or above students only.
2. Not for students who have taken GESH4010.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #1 No Poverty
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #4 Quality Education
SDG-GE #5 Gender Equality
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
Experiential Learning Course
Service Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
This is a 13-week programme that consists of two components: *Social and Civic Learning* and *Investigation &* *Initial Planning*.

| **Topic** | **Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Social & Civic Learning | This module focuses on three core aspects: 1. Social and Emotional Learning 2. Citizenship Skills 3. Employability Skills This module aims to provide students with soft and hard skills for service-learning activities through lectures and skills labs. |
| Investigation & Initial Planning | In this module, students will engage in the investigation of community needs, and identify the potential actions to do. These are the suggested fields of study: 1. Environmental sustainability 2. Health and well-being 3. Quality education 4. Poverty and inequalities Students will form groups to investigate and understand the community to identify the specific need that they would like to address. Upon completing the investigation, students are expected to formulate initial ideas for their service plan in preparation for taking GESH2012. |

courses.subject: GESH
courses.title: Service-learning: Action towards Personhood

meetings.instructor:
Dr SHIK Wai Yan Angela, 
Miss FUNG Wing Yan

Dr SHIK Wai Yan Angela, 
Miss FUNG Wing Yan

Dr SHIK Wai Yan Angela, 
Miss FUNG Wing Yan

Dr SHIK Wai Yan Angela,

courses.description: This course intends to integrate their academic knowledge and skills to address community needs in collaboration with local community partners. Applying the fundamental skillset and mindset equipped in GESH2011, students would implement their service-learning project in local communities. Through a series of self-initiated service, self-reflection, and project presentations, students would consolidate their insights and experience from community service and be directed to examine the meaning and value of university education in real life. This experiential learning approach would facilitate students’ self-development and foster their civic-mindedness in creating changes in the community.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students who have already taken GESH2011 only.
Not for students who have taken GESH4010.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-SE #1 No Poverty
SDG-SE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-SE #4 Quality Education
SDG-SE #5 Gender Equality
SDG-SE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-SE #13 Climate Action
SDG-SE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-SE #17 Partnerships for the Goals
Experiential Learning Course
Service Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
This is a 13-week programme that consists of three components, namely *Action*, *Reflection* and *Demonstration*.

| **Topic** | **Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Action | This Action component focuses on the implementation of community service in solving a social need. These are the suggested fields: 1. Environmental sustainability 2. Health and well-being 3. Quality education 4. Poverty and inequalities Students will act according to their proposal to address community needs. They need to map out a detailed and practical proposal for their actions to take in collaboration with their community partners. They are encouraged to document the process of their service. The below elements need to be included: * Application of multi-disciplinary skills and knowledge and concepts of civic engagement * Direct interaction with service recipients, community members, community partners, or local organisations/ representatives Through the experiential learning approach, this module aims to reinforce or examine students’ skills and knowledge in the classroom. |
| Reflection | The Reflection component comprises two dimensions to maximise their learning: * Service-Learning Reflection * Self-reflection After completing the community service, each group are encouraged to discuss the following core questions in their poster presentation: 1. What was the significance of your service? 2. What did you learn during your service that reinforces/ contradicts your learning gained in the classroom? 3. What are the difficulties encountered when addressing those SDGs in the local context? 4. What is the relationship of your Service-Learning Project (SLP) to the “real world”? While each student is expected to write a portfolio, projecting their personal growth in terms of the meaning of knowledge and life. They could discuss three core questions: 1. What insights did you gain through your project that might assist you in your career or in selecting a career? 2. What impact might your project have on your life-long learning process? 3. What did you learn about community involvement, citizenship and civic responsibility? |
| Demonstration | In this module, students will demonstrate what they have learned throughout the process of service-learning through a more formal presentation, including a review of their proposal, community service, new findings, suggestions and reflections. This module aims to consolidate their leanings and extend the impact of their project to others through sharing their experiences. |

courses.subject: GESH
courses.title: Work and Productive Life

meetings.instructor:
Dr. KWOK Andrew John, 
Professor MA Ching Wan Ronald

courses.description: For senior year students entering a life of work, this course intends to be a bridge between formal university education and work life. The goal is to broaden the concept of work beyond vocation, by developing a deep understanding of the nature of work and its broad array of possibilities. Throughout the course, students would be directed to appreciate the many realms of life experiences over and beyond work towards the focal concept of a productive life. As students are approaching the end of their university life, this course would be an opportune framework for examining the meaning and value of university education in real life.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For S.H. Ho College Year 3 or above students only.
Not for students who have taken GESH2011 or 2012.
courses.course_syllabus:
This capstone course for S.H. Ho College general education will begin with a series of discussions on work life through different perspectives including practical, intellectual, career-directed and case-orientated approaches, complemented with reading assignments. This will be followed by adjoining projects carried out by student teams, facilitated by college teachers and peers.

This course encourages variation in students' work such as research study, documentary production, reflective essay and creative project.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Early Feedback Collection System
* Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
* Student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Required readings differ according to different teachers.
